Le 06-03-24 =E0 07:20, Claude Montpetit a =E9crit :
> Thus, I prefer the d=
ifferent language variants of a resource to be
> accessible with different =
URIs. But content-neg is useful when  
> accessing
> the resource the first=
 time using the URI that does not have the  
> variant
> info. Then ideally=
, from a user's perspective again, it is nice

> page explicitl=
y displays the other available languages as links.

Once upon in a time, th=
ere was a proposal to be able to access  
through HTTP headers, the list of=
 different variants of the same URI.  
But it stayed in an experimental sta=
ge.

http://gewis.win.tue.nl/~koen/conneg/

[[[
Transparent Content Negotia=
tion in HTTP

     HTTP allows web site authors to put multiple versions of=
 the  
same information under a single URL. Transparent content negotiation=
  
(TCN) is an extensible negotiation mechanism, layered on top of HTTP,  
=
for automatically selecting the best version when the URL is  
accessed. Th=
is enables the smooth deployment of new web data formats  
and markup tags.=

]]]

-- Transparent Content Negotiation in HTTP home page
